text.p: Global temperatures are linked to the concentration of greenhouse gases (GHG) in the atmosphere and we are heading for a catastrophic rise in excess of 3°C this century. This is a global average covering extreme variations across continents and regions. According to the IPCC we will see more severe and frequent extreme weather events in the near future like floods, droughts, wildfires and hurricanes.
The UNEP Climate Action Dashboard shows you the global state of the climate emergency with its impact on extreme weather events across the world[a][b]

text.p: As the world is heading for a catastrophic rise in excess of 3°C this century, we will see more severe and frequent extreme weather events in the near future like floods, droughts, wildfires and hurricanes according to the IPCC. To limit this to 1.5°C, we need to cut emissions by 30 gigatones annually by 2030.

article.title: Ocean temperature
article.alt: This world map shows the temperature of the top millimeter of the ocean's surface. Sea surface temperature influences weather, including hurricanes, as well as plant and animal life in the ocean.
article.head: Ocean Temperature Map bla bla[d]

text.p: As the world is heading for a catastrophic rise in excess of 3°C this century, oceans are absorbing 90 % of the heat and a third of the GHG. It has slowed the visible impacts of the warming planet yet leading to warmer and more acidic waters affecting marine life and ecosystems as well as the communities relying on them for livelihoods.

article.title: Fires
article.imgtitle: A decade of fires (monthly data from 2010 to 2021)
article.alt: This world map shows a decade of burning fires. Fire plays a major role in Earth's carbon cycle by releasing carbon into the air, and by consuming trees that would otherwise absorb carbon from the air during photosynthesis.
article.head: More frequent fires around the world[e]

text.p: As the world is heading for a catastrophic rise in excess of 3°C this century, we will see more severe and frequent extreme weather events in the near future. While the global temperature is a world average, we will see many more heatwaves and droughts causing wildfires that will in turn emit GHG from the forests burned while threatening biodiversity, economy and human health.

text.p: The maps were produced using imagery by the NASA Earth Observations team using data courtesy of the MODIS Land Science team at NASA Goddard Space Flight Center.
The sea surface temperature map shows an estimate of the warmth of the ocean's “skin” (top millimeter).
The land temperature map shows temperature anomalies of the “skin” of the land surface for a given month compared to the average conditions during that period in 2001-2010.
The animated fire map shows the locations of fires over the past decade.
The maps were recolored and reprojected to the Equal Earth projection.
Data for the climate risk table comes from Eckstein, David & Künzel, Vera & Schäfer, Laura. (2021), 'Global Climate Risk Index 2021', GermanWatch.
